Situation1: They casually answer a mentee’s occasional questions during breaks.
Expectation2: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation2: A patient has a combination of unusual symptoms that are not immediately linked to a single known illness.
Story: I sat in the staff lounge, sipping lukewarm coffee, when my mentee, Sarah, slid into the seat beside me. She had that eager look, notebook in hand, ready to ask about the nuances of patient communication. I wanted to give her my full attention, to share the lessons I’d learned over years of practice. But my mind kept drifting back to the patient in exam room three—a middle-aged man with a fever, joint pain, and a rash that didn’t fit any textbook pattern. The lab results were inconclusive, and I knew I needed to focus, to piece together the puzzle before his condition worsened. Yet, Sarah’s questions tugged at me; she looked up to me, expecting guidance and wisdom. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, the urge to mentor and the duty to diagnose, each demanding my presence in different ways. My heart pounded as I tried to decide where I was needed most, torn between nurturing a future doctor and saving a patient in the present.
